newsitem.title: USA: Gore China trip vindicates U.S. policy - Clinton.
newsitem.headline: Gore China trip vindicates U.S. policy - Clinton.

text.p: President Bill Clinton said on Thursday he believed Vice President Al Gore's visit to China had gone well and validated his administration's policy of engagement with Beijing.

"I think that the trip has been a real validation for our strategy of engagement with China, of taking our agreements, our disagreements ... directly to them," Clinton said in response to a question at a White House event on health care.
Clinton told reporters he had spoken to Gore on Thursday morning, adding: "He is very pleased with the results so far and I certainly am very pleased with the work he's done."
"I'm encouraged about it, I think the trip has been well worth making," he added.

The most senior U.S. official to visit China since the crackdown on student demonstrations in Beijing in 1989, Gore's talks with Chinese leaders covered a wide range of tricky topics including human rights, trade disputes and Taiwan.

Gore also told the Chinese an investigation into reports China tried to make donations to U.S. politicians should not affect Sino-U.S. relations -- but would be a serious matter if such charges were proved. China has denied the allegations.

Clinton made no reference to the fund-raising controversy nor to Gore's public relations difficulties during the visit, which included one Gore aide contradicting another on what the vice president had told the Chinese on the controversy.
